terms.definition: Enterprise Resource Planning - a software system that integrates and manages core business processes across departments like finance, inventory, production, sales, and HR in real-time.
A technology platform that captures, stores, organizes, and shares an organization's collective knowledge and information to improve decision-making and efficiency.
The process of combining data from different sources and systems into a unified, consistent view that can be accessed and analyzed across an organization.
A software service that runs on remote servers accessed via the internet, rather than being installed locally on individual computers or servers.
The ability for multiple users to work together simultaneously on the same document or project, with changes visible instantly to all participants.
A software system that stores, tracks, and manages electronic documents and images, providing version control and access permissions.
A centralized digital storage location where organizational knowledge, documents, and information assets are systematically organized and maintained.
The process of ensuring that data remains consistent and up-to-date across multiple systems, databases, or applications.
The capability of software to display content and interface elements in multiple languages to serve global audiences.
A system that tracks and manages changes to documents or code over time, allowing users to access previous versions and track modifications.
Tools that collect, analyze, and present data about system usage, performance, and user behavior to help optimize operations.
The process of collecting and documenting valuable information, insights, and expertise from various sources within an organization.
Comprehensive documentation systems designed for large organizations that include policies, procedures, technical guides, and knowledge bases.
The process of analyzing and improving business processes to increase efficiency, reduce errors, and eliminate redundancies.
A security system that grants different levels of access and editing rights to users based on their assigned roles within an organization.
